misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that array elements cannot be compared directly within a conditional statement and must first be extracted into individual local variables to be evaluated.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: In Java, array access expressions (like 'z[j]') evaluate to the value stored at that index. They can be used directly in any context where a value of that type is valid, including within comparison operators, without needing to be 'unpacked' into local variables first.
misconceptions.error_manifestation: Redundant memory allocation and value copying occurring in every iteration of the inner loop, regardless of whether a swap is necessary.

misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that for an array of size 'n', a bubble-sort-style algorithm must iterate through the entire sequence of pairs exactly 'n' times to guarantee the elements are fully sorted.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: In a bubble sort, 'n-1' passes are sufficient to sort 'n' elements, as the positioning of the final element is guaranteed once all others are placed. Furthermore, the student fails to recognize that each pass 'i' reduces the number of elements that need to be checked in the inner loop (as the 'i' largest values are already settled).
misconceptions.error_manifestation: Inefficient execution with redundant passes and redundant comparisons of already-sorted elements at the end of the array.

misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that to swap two values in an array, both values must be captured into separate temporary variables simultaneously to avoid data loss.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: A swap only requires one temporary variable to hold one value while the other is overwritten. By assigning both 'z[j]' and 'z[j+1]' to 'a' and 'b' respectively, the student uses more temporary storage than required (two integers instead of one).
misconceptions.error_manifestation: Redundant variable assignments (two assignments to 'a' and 'b' vs one assignment to a 'temp').
